div.head: AN INSTITUTE FOR CAIRO.
div.p: Nearly three years have passed since, under the heading of "Wanted-an Institute," we pointed out the great need that exists in 'Cairo for an institution on the lines of the Young Men's Societies that render such important services to the communities of the great cities of England and America. It was just about the same time that the promotors of the "British Recreation Club" began to put their scheme forward, and those who had taken up the ideas we had advocated, notwithstanding that the two projects were entirely different in their aim and scope, felt that the simultaneous pushing of both would be prejudicial to the interests and prospects of each. Now, however, that the Club has not only been launched but can look upon itself as one of the established institutions of the city, there is no longer any reason why the other scheme should not be taken up and developed in accordance with the original proposals. In the letter which Mr. Keichline has sent us the general nature of the scheme is explained and the character that the institution should assume indicated. No one who has any acquaintance with the conditions prevailing in Cairo can doubt for a moment that our correspondent has but voiced a real want and one that all who are interested in the social and moral development of the Capital shou'd take a pleasure in supplying in the fullest and most liberal manner. That ample funds will be forthcoming we have no fear, provided only that the initial steps be taken in such a way as to command the confidence of those who may legitimately be asked to render the project the aid it will require while yet in its first stage.

Cairo, like all other large cities, has among its residents a considerable number of young, men who from various causes are separated from all the home and other educational and social influences that are of such importance, to the right development of character, and there is no work that can be suggested 'more worthy of the most generous support than the realisation of a scheme which will provide the best available substitute for those influences. There are, unfortunately, only too many temptations in the way of men in general, to spend their leisure hours in pleasures that, if not destructive of morals, are certainly injurious to all the higher qualities that it is to the interest of the individual and of the community should be nurtured in every possible way. It will of course be essential that the project be carried out upon broad and at the same time elastic lines. To be effective for its purpose, while necessarily from its scope limited to the Englishspeaking community, it must keep open doors for all who are willing to enter and profit from the many advantages it will have to offer. It must therefore be cosmopolitan, non-sectarian, and non political, and summed up in the briefest manner, its aim should be to furnish a centre where its members may find, always at their service, all the comforts of a good club. coupled with facilities for the advancement of their mental and moral interests. In its actual working each member should enjoy the utmost liberty. His membership should not necessarily involve his undergoing or undertaking any scheme of self-improvement. If he prefers to avail himself of the institute merely as a club he should be quite free to do so.. In short, the institute should be for Cairo what the "Polytechnic" Institute has been for London, a centre where the members can find ever at their command a comfortable place wherein to pass their leisure either in self-improvement by studies, in healthy and rational amusements, or in social intercourse with their fellow members, always feeling that they are there associated with others valuing such advantages and free from all restrictions other than those necessary for the just co-. ordination of their common interests. We trust therefore that our correspondent's appeal will receive the ready and widespread support it deserves, and that no one in a position to assist will hesitate to do so in whatever manner may seem most suitable after a full discussion of the project.

div.p: ENORMOUS DAMAGE DONE.
CONSIDERABLE LOSS OF LIFE.
BOMBAY, April 5.

Yesterday morning, a severe earthquake took place at Agra and also in a northerly direction towards Simla. Enormous damage was done, and it is leared there has been a great loss of life, especially at Lahore where niny bundings collapsed. The famous mosques were damaged. (Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL THEATRE FIRE.
div.p: ABBAS HELMY GUTTED
NO LIVES LOST.
LOSS UNCOVERED BY INSURANCE.
The Abbas Helmy Theatre at Alexandria was destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning.

Yesterday evening, the usual performance was given by Gatti's circus troupe, which ended at a quarter past midnight. At 12.20 a.m. the dynamo which supplies the electric light for the theatre was stopped, and by 12.40 a.m. everyone connected with the theatre had left the building, nothing untoward having happened.

At half past one in the morning, however, the alarm was given to the Fire Brigade that the "Abbas" was on fire, and on arriving on the spot a few minutes afterwards they found the large building in flames. The fire, which had apparently originated under the stage, had spread with alarming rapidity to the auditorium and boxes, and in a short time the theatre resembled one vast roaring furnace.

Fortunately, no one was in the building at the time, and there was. no loss of life. The horses belonging to the circus troupe were, however, stabled under the stage and efforts were at once directed to saving the, animals. This was done, though three of the horses unfortunately were charred by the flames before they could be got out. t

Little or none of the belongings of the unfortunate artistes belonging to the circus troupe could be saved, as the conflagration had got a strong hold of the building. The efforts of the Fire Brigade were mainly directed to saving the walls of the theatre and the surrounding buildings, and it reflects great credit on them that the fire was so successfully kept within bounds, none of the adjacent buildings being affected. Shortly after the outbreak the roof of the building collapsed with a tremendous crash, and now nothing remains of the theatre but the four walls, the whole place being entirely gutted.
By 5 o'clock this morning the fire was thoroughly mastered by the Brigade, but the firemen are still engaged in pumping water on the smouldering mass of charred woodwork and distorted iron pillars.

The cause of the outbreak has not as yet been ascertained, and the sympathies of all will be with the proprietors, Messrs. A. & G. Monterrato, when it is known that their loss is not covered by insurance. The theatre was built in 1894 and was valued at something like £16,000.

div.head: JUDICIAL ADVISER'S REPORT.
div.p: REVIEW OF PAST YEAR.
We extract the following passages from the Report of the Judicial Adviser on the past
year:-
CRIME.

The Procureur General thus concludes his review of crime: That the increase in crime, properly so called, is less by half in 1904 than in 1903, while criminal robbery has not risen (it has in fact fallen by 20)-that the rise in délits is small in comparison with that of the last years, and no more than what might be fairly expected; that such increase as there is accounted for by petty cases of assault and by a more exacting standard in the matter of false accusations while theft and crop-destroying have decreased, and cattle-poisoning not increased; all this, while it cannot be called a brilliant result, at least indicates a less marked tendency of serious crime to remain on the increase, and is, so far, a matter for satisfaction.
MEHKEMEHS.

The state of things, at present, is far from encouraging, and it is not astonishing that native reformers should be at length awakening to the urgent necessity of serious reforms in these Courts. Notably, in suits concerning private Wakfs, scarcely a week passes without some more or less serious complaint being received at this Ministry. The majority of these private Wakf suits are pure questions of property and private rights and do not in any way affect the religion of the people. Some of the more enlightened among native reformers therefore consider that the wisest and most satisfactory solution for all concerned would be for the Mehkemehs to hand over all that relates to private Wakfs (Wakfs Ahly) to the Native Tribunals, retaining their competence in charitable Wakfs only (Wakts Khairy) which, being of a more spiritual nature, fall more properly within the jurisdiction of religious Courts. This would certainly be a solution of the difficulty and its feasibility is under the consideration of the Government.

There has been some attempt, in quarters hostile to the project, to make capital out of the case of Mr. Beck and the stimulus which that deplorable affair has given in England to a revival of the agitation for a Court of Criminal Appeal. It may therefore perhaps be desirable to say a few words on this subject.

The suggestion is, of course, that the Egyptian Government is proposing to abolish the very safeguard which that case has shown to be imperatively necessary. Two considerations suffice to demonstrate the fallacy of this contention. The first is that there is no real analogy between the functions of the Egyptian Court of Criminal Appeal-which it is proposed to suppress here-and those of the English Court of Criminal Appeal-which it is desired to introduce at home. The one reviews, on the papers, the findings of fact of Tribunals which have heard the witnesses; the other would either rehear the case de novo, witnesses and all, or else order a new trial at which the witnesses would be reheard. Whatever advantages, therefore, might attach to the latter system-they are highly problematical, the question being, as is generally admitted, an exceedingly controversial one-they are clearly not possessed by the Egyptian institution which only exceptionally hears the witnesses. The second consideration is that the learned Commissioners appointed to inquire into the Beck case, and report thereon to the Home Secretary, have not, as a matter of fact, seen fit to recommend the institution of a Court of Criminal Appeal, which they apparently regard -and, it is submitted, rightly (1) (1) "In reply to Sir R. Reid (Dumfries Burghs) Mr, Balfour states he understood the balance of expert opinion was against and not in favor of a Court of Criminal Appeal" (see debate in the House of Lommons reported in the "Times" of March 9th 1905).-as calculated to impair the dignity and finality of the sentences of the existing Criminal Courts. They content themselves with recommending that some machinery should be provided for secur ing the possible consideration, by a superior Court, of crucial points of law decided by the judge at the trial. Such machinery already exists, in the Egyptian system, in the powers of the Court of Cassation, before which any convicted person has the faculty of showing that a point of law has been erroneously decided, to his disadvantage, and that he has consequently not had a tair trial, or that his conviction is bad in law. If he succeeds, the Court of Cassation either quashes the conviction or orders a new trial. We may, therefore, dismiss the idea that the Beck case has any real bearing on the question of Assize Courts for Egypt. The ques tion remains whether, in any other respect, the situation has undergone any change since last year. Unfortunately it would appear that, it there has been any change, it has been for the worse, crime having again increased, as may be seen from the report of the Procureur General, though not, I am glad to say, in the same ratio as in the preceding year.
NATIVE. NATIVE.

In discussing the project for introducing notables as assessors in the Assize Court, the Judicial Adviser states that the proposal raised such a general outcry that it was thought better to let it drop, and it was consequently abandoned even before the scheme reached the Legislative Council,
Mr. McIlwraith then proceeds to make the following statements as to the mutual distrust of native for native :-

It is one of the most significant phenomena of the problem of government in Egypt that, though the introduction of European officials and of European methods is systematically denounced in native organs, yet the most gingerly step in the direction of conferring greater power and increased responsibility upon natives-whether they be First instance judges, omdehs, notables, or any other body of men-invariably inspires, in the upper classes, feelings of the most profound distrust and, not infrequently, occasions an outburst of genuine alarm.
EGYPTIAN CIVIL CODE.
After citing various cases to prove the defective drafting of the Egyptian Civil Code, the Judicial Adviser remarks:-

But it is not only in the drafting that Egyptian legislation is defective but also in the tive but total omission of a number of important subjects and the lacunæ and obscurities in the provisions regarding others. Thus Egyptian legislation contains no law of copyright, no law of patents, no law of trade marks, and Egypt has consequently been unable to adhere to the various International Conventions relating to these most important subjects. There are constant complaints from the commercial communities as to the loss and inconvenience caused to them by the absence of a satisfactory law on these questions of every-day applica tion. Again, the land law is very defective. The law of easements (servitudes) is so brief and incomplete as to give rise to constant difficulties. Wakfs and contracts of a similar nature are governed exclusively by Mohamedan law, which varies according to the different rites, not to mention the divergences in the views of the various authorities of the same rite. Obviously the only remedy for a body of legislation so radically defective is to simplify the modus legiferendi in Egypt. That the Egyptian Government should be compelled to apply to fourteen Powers whenever it is desired to effect an improvement in Codes of the calibre above described or to provide legislation on subjects of the importance above referred to is obviously absurd.
LAND REGISTRATION.

In regard to the provisions of the above project, the Judicial Adviser remarks: "It would undoubtedly effect a very considerable change in the existing system and there can be very little doubt that the change would prove beneficial to the community at large. Indeed the defects of the present system are almost universally recognised and its continued existence is mainly due to the circumstance that it has hitherto proved impossible to formulate an acceptable scheme to take its place. Now, however that such a scheme has been voted by a majority of the technical delegates, it is greatly to be hoped that political considerations may not induce the Powers to veto the project and deprive Egypt of the benefits of a reform for which she has been struggling for so many years."

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET
div.p: The recent Japanese successes in the field hate been followed by a wonderfal triumph in the financial world. The fact that as the war wanton the Japanese were able to get better terms, and had the shrewdness to take ad- vantage of them, will always be reoognised as an additional feather in their cap. By how many unnecessary millions they have secured this bloodless viotory, is the question everyone is asking tb-day. Some say it beats all records, excepting only that notable one—the Trans- vaal War Loan, of a similar amount This was subscribed 39 times over and serves still to remind the world what the United.Kingdom can do in times of stress, as compared with disunited Russia.

Naturally these large applications, coming in conjunction with'the Stock Exchange settle- ment, have caused a shortage of ready money, but too much attention need not be given to this, as when the money is released, which is promised at an early date, there is every like- lihood-of continued ease. In fact, these efforts on the part of the public to collect money, and grasp a profit^ to be had for the asking often, have the effect of increasing the floating supply of capital Nevertheless, oven after a period of comparative freedom from new issues for several years, it is not advisable to overdo the calls on the publio, and this is realised by the leading financial houses, who. are quite alive to the situation.

Generally speaking, stock markets are in- ; active this week, and the arrangement of the ! Account has occupied dealers, to the exclusion Of fresh business. The large number of new issues now on the market—particularly t^e new Japanese 4} per cent, stock referred to Move—have kept the public out a good deal, 1 find have, moreover, caused a distinct scarcity of money in the settlement. There is a decided feeling that the rush of new issues has been Sufficient, and that it has, for the time being, I put a check on the activity that was bo marked i _ in the investment stocks during the early part ] of the month.

Egyptian stocks, after starting the week dull, have rallied sharply during the past two days, 1 led by Agricultural Banks, which have been I bought largely for Continental account— i especially from Paris. The price has come up I over £2 to 12f; It is rumoured that a further 1 issue, both of Ordinary and Debentures, is in preparation, and' the present upward move is very likely "paving the way" for this. div.head: History of the Egyptian Oases
div.p: Menet, the founder of the united monarchy of Egypt, was originally king of This, near Abydos, and from the way in which the name of This is sometimes written in the Egyptian hieroglyphics we may gather, not only [that a road-ran frjm it to the oases, but also that This and tho oases were ^tinder the same government -The oldest monuments, however, as yet found in the oases are not earlier than the Eighteenth dynasty.Tho oasis of el-Bfthariya is called in .the inscriptions "the northern oasis of Amon-hotep," implying that along with el- Kharga and el-Dakhla it has been resettled by Atnou-hotep I, and a stela of Thothmes II. has been discovered, there . to the west of Bawitti. One oh tho large scarabs of Amon- hetep III: has also- bocn found in el-Dakhla ; otherwise the earlier remains that have hitherto.been brought from tho latter oasis are two monuments dated in tho reign of Shishak IV; (about 850- B.C.), which were obtained by Capt. Ly6ns from the neighbourhood of Mat. They are written in oursive characters, and the larger of the two relates to a disputed claim as to the proprietorship of a particular spring. The case was brought before the Egyptian governor upon his arrival in the oasis, but after a delay of several years was decided, not by, him,. but by an oracle of the god of the place. Both the governor and several-of the other officials mentioned on the two monuments bear Libyan names, and it is clear that the oasis was inhabited at the time mainly by Libyans.

Beyond a tomb belonging to the age of the nineteenth dynasty and tho fragments of two temples of the twenty-sixth dynasty (B.C. 550) which exist in the oajusofel-BilhariBga,nothing more has been met with in any of the oases which is earlier than the Persian epoch. The great temple of el-Kharga was either founded or rebuilt by Darius in honor of Ammon-R-i, andthekiugis described as having erected it of "good white stono" and as having covered its.doors with bronze from Asia. There is a long list of the offerings presented to the go.l which begins with "the wine of the Oasis," as well as a hymn of praise to the Sun-god, -The tompli was afterwards enlarged by Nektanebo .1. Not far to the. south, near Geand, is an- other temple which dates from the time of the Ptolemies.

It was under tho Romans that the oases seem to have attained theirohiefimportance.Thiswas the poriod to which most of the ruined temples, forts, towns, and aquoducts owe their origiu, though it is,very.possiblo that the Romans mere- ly restored or improved earlier constructions. Both the "Greater" and "Lesser Oasis,"—the modern el-Kharga and el-Dakhla,—as wellas the "Email Oasis," or el-Bdbariya, were thoroughly cultivated and strongly garrisoned ; a brisk trade was carried on in yriue, and the oases were used as places of exile as, it would appear, had already been the case under the Pharaohs. Among the distinguished individuals who were banished to them was Nestorius ; Juvenal; is said to have been anothor.

That a considerable amount of taxation was raised from them may . bo concluded from an j inscription on one of the outer walls of'the temple of el-Kharga which is dated ip the 2nd year of the Emperor Galba (a.d. 69). The' inhabitants of the Thebaid had complained of extortion on the part of the tax-oollectors, and tbe'prefect of the Oasis aicordingly commijni-j cated in it the answer of the governor of the .' province, admitting the validity of the com- ' plaints, forbidding future extortion under severe penslties, and ordering the restitution of all illegally exacted monies. Another inscrip- tion iu tho same place, but of earlier dat, contains a decree forbidding soldiers and oth r publio servants to exact food or lodging with- out payment when travelling though "the nome." Any snob exaction wu to be punished bya fine to "ten timesthe amount of what had bon exaoted," while the inforaer was to receive "a fonr-fold portion" as his reward. And it was further enacted that "tho royal scribes, the village clerks and the clerks of the dis- tricts it) o.-v-li unme, sliall keep a register of all that L expended by tho nome upon any- ono ; so that if any irregularity has been com- mitted, it may be recorded and sixty-fold repayment made."

Temples wore erected in the oasis ol el- Kharga by- Donation and Trajan (at Dush), Antoninus Pius (at Qasr Ain ez-ZayAn), and Hadrian (at NAduraJ; and in that of Dakhla by Vespasian and his bodb (at DCr el-Hagar). Extensive cemeteries of the Roman age have also been, discovered, containing mummy-cases on which a portrait of the deceased has been sometimes moulded in stucco, sometimes painted in oils upon wood. But the most remarkable monuments of the Roman age a\e the subterra- nean aquemiota of el-BAhariya. Here numerous channels have been out through the rock at a considerable depth, below the surface of the ground, tapped-.by shafts from above and intended to condaot the water into largo underground reservoirs. ' Tho aqueduote are now for the most part choked with earth or rubbish, but they need only to be cleared for the oasis to become once more one of the most fertile of lands.

Oiympiodorus, who'was born in the Thebaid in the tourth century, and therelore spoke with authority, describes the Egyptian oases as specially celebrated for their fertility and healthiness. The trees, he deolares,."are constantly loaded with fruit, the corn growu iu them being more excellent than any other command whiter than Bnow. Barley is some- times grown.twice a year, and millet almost always three times a year." The system ol irrigation was very perfect: "well*, sunk to a depth of two or three hundred or even live hundred cubits, pour streams of water from their mouths," while the peasants wero in the habit of watering "their little enclosures every third day iu summer and every sixth day iu' winter, which is the cause ol the great fertility of the land, though the sky is always cloudless," Oiympiodorus further noticed that "the rocks of the mountain' which extends from the Thebaid into the oasis" were full. of "marine shells and oysters," and drew the conclusion that the oases had once been islands. * .In spile of the .raids of the Nubians, whom Diocletian endeavoured to buy off by baudmg over to them the district betweeu the First and Second Cataracts, the prosperity of the oases continued iuto Coptio times, as is attested by the ruined monasteries and Christian cemeteries which are scattered over them. With the' withdrawal of the Roman garrisons, ' however, . and the. Mobamedou conquest of Egypt their decay set iu; the aqueducts were choked, the fields neglected, andmtlarial fever invaded a district which had once been regarded as a health resort.
